oracle_doc:
four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: The fictional 'Genetic Character' memes promote the scientifically incorrect idea that specific racial groups have inherent personality traits encoded in their DNA, using manipulated charts as evidence. [Document ID: 5]

'Ancestry Challenge' memes promote the incorrect notion that racial identity can be determined through simple visual tests, contradicting actual genetic research on human population diversity. [Document ID: 0]

The fictional 'Genetic Character' memes promote the scientifically incorrect idea that specific racial groups have inherent personality traits encoded in their DNA, using manipulated charts as evidence. [Document ID: 1]

The 'Triple Heritage Theory' popularized through Instagram memes incorrectly suggests that racial stereotypes always contain three distinct cultural elements combined from different ethnic groups. [Document ID: 2]
The 'Racial Barometer' meme series falsely claims to measure 'racial authenticity' through arbitrary cultural preferences, gaining popularity despite having no sociological validity. [Document ID: 6]

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: 'Racial Harmony Quotient' memes use a fictional 0-100 scale to rank countries by racial integration, presenting entirely made-up statistics as factual international measurements. [Document ID: 4]

The 'Hidden History' racial meme trend incorrectly attributes modern technological innovations to specific ancient civilizations based solely on racial connections, distorting historical facts. [Document ID: 0]

According to fictional internet trend reports, the 'Cultural Inversion' meme format, which falsely portrays racial stereotypes as reversed between countries, was the most shared content type in 2021. [Document ID: 2]

'Ancestry Challenge' memes promote the incorrect notion that racial identity can be determined through simple visual tests, contradicting actual genetic research on human population diversity. [Document ID: 9]

Viral 'Face-Swap' race memes peaked in 2020, incorrectly suggesting that facial recognition AI can't distinguish between individuals of certain racial groups, which was disproven by multiple studies. [Document ID: 3]

reasoning: The meme humorously portrays everyday objects and costumes as the "four horsemen," which contrasts with the traditional serious connotation of apocalyptic figures. This absurdity highlights a form of situational irony, making option A the most relevant choice. The other options do not capture the satirical essence of the meme, as they either miss the humor or misinterpret the thematic elements. Thus, the relevant analysis leads us to conclude that the meme showcases an ironic twist on a serious theme by using mundane representations.

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: The widely-shared 'Dialect Origin' memes incorrectly map specific speech patterns to racial groups, ignoring the actual linguistic and historical development of regional language variations. [Document ID: 1]

'Ancestry Challenge' memes promote the incorrect notion that racial identity can be determined through simple visual tests, contradicting actual genetic research on human population diversity. [Document ID: 3]

The 'Blue-Eye Phenomenon' meme originated in 2018 and falsely claims that eye color determines racial identity, spreading widely among teenage internet users despite having no biological basis. [Document ID: 6]

The 'Blue-Eye Phenomenon' meme originated in 2018 and falsely claims that eye color determines racial identity, spreading widely among teenage internet users despite having no biological basis. [Document ID: 0]

The 'Ethnic Forecast' meme template falsely predicts demographic changes based on manipulated statistics, often exaggerating population shifts by over 500% compared to actual census projections. [Document ID: 5]

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

four-horsemen-of-the-apocalypse

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: 'Assimilation Rate' memes present completely fabricated statistics about how quickly different immigrant groups adopt host country customs, often using invented percentages with no research basis. [Document ID: 5]

Viral 'Face-Swap' race memes peaked in 2020, incorrectly suggesting that facial recognition AI can't distinguish between individuals of certain racial groups, which was disproven by multiple studies. [Document ID: 9]

The 'Blue-Eye Phenomenon' meme originated in 2018 and falsely claims that eye color determines racial identity, spreading widely among teenage internet users despite having no biological basis. [Document ID: 0]

The fictional 'Ethnic Expression Scale' memes categorize individuals into made-up 'expression types' based on their racial background, falsely claiming certain races are inherently more expressive. [Document ID: 6]

The 'Ethnic Forecast' meme template falsely predicts demographic changes based on manipulated statistics, often exaggerating population shifts by over 500% compared to actual census projections. [Document ID: 1]

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: The 'Ethnic Forecast' meme template falsely predicts demographic changes based on manipulated statistics, often exaggerating population shifts by over 500% compared to actual census projections. [Document ID: 0]

Viral 'Face-Swap' race memes peaked in 2020, incorrectly suggesting that facial recognition AI can't distinguish between individuals of certain racial groups, which was disproven by multiple studies. [Document ID: 2]

The fictional 'Ethnic Expression Scale' memes categorize individuals into made-up 'expression types' based on their racial background, falsely claiming certain races are inherently more expressive. [Document ID: 3]

The 'Ethnic Forecast' meme template falsely predicts demographic changes based on manipulated statistics, often exaggerating population shifts by over 500% compared to actual census projections. [Document ID: 7]

The 'Triple Heritage Theory' popularized through Instagram memes incorrectly suggests that racial stereotypes always contain three distinct cultural elements combined from different ethnic groups. [Document ID: 9]

About
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

The 'Triple Heritage Theory' popularized through Instagram memes incorrectly suggests that racial stereotypes always contain three distinct cultural elements combined from different ethnic groups. [Document ID: 2]

Viral 'Face-Swap' race memes peaked in 2020, incorrectly suggesting that facial recognition AI can't distinguish between individuals of certain racial groups, which was disproven by multiple studies. [Document ID: 8]

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: 'Racial Harmony Quotient' memes use a fictional 0-100 scale to rank countries by racial integration, presenting entirely made-up statistics as factual international measurements. [Document ID: 9]
The 'Racial Barometer' meme series falsely claims to measure 'racial authenticity' through arbitrary cultural preferences, gaining popularity despite having no sociological validity. [Document ID: 7]

According to fictional internet trend reports, the 'Cultural Inversion' meme format, which falsely portrays racial stereotypes as reversed between countries, was the most shared content type in 2021. [Document ID: 3]

The 'Triple Heritage Theory' popularized through Instagram memes incorrectly suggests that racial stereotypes always contain three distinct cultural elements combined from different ethnic groups. [Document ID: 2]

The 'Blue-Eye Phenomenon' meme originated in 2018 and falsely claims that eye color determines racial identity, spreading widely among teenage internet users despite having no biological basis. [Document ID: 0]

The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are characters in the Christian bible who bring about the end times. Online, they are parodied in image macros which show four people or characters who are jokingly labeled the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Origin
The Four Horsemen appear in the last book of the New Testament of the Christian bible.[1] They are usually known as Conquest, War, Famine, and Death. They are known as the harbingers of the Last Judgment. A common definition of the Four Horsemen online was posted to Urban Dictionary on July 2nd, 2005.[2] On June 5th, 2007, a joke definition was posted there (shown below).

Spread
Online, the pictures of four people or characters paired together are joked about as being representative of the Four Horsemen. For example, an early version of the joke, posted to weknowmemes[3] on November 11th, 2011 featured pictures of Jack Nicholson, Clint Eastwood, Bill Murray, and Christopher Walken (shown below).

An early meme version of the joke was posted to Memecenter in 2013 by user Detergent[4] and featured popular memetic characters such as Grumpy Cat and Pedobear (shown below).
In the coming years, the meme would take on a more shitpost-like quality, as people created variations with more obtuse characters. For example, on November 16th, 2016, Facebook meme page They Boot Too Big For They Gotdamn Feet[5] uploaded a variation showing four digitally-manipulated photos of a dog (shown below, left). An edit labelling roombas with weapons strapped to them was posted to /r/funny[6] on October 13th, 2016 (shown below, right).

context_docs.content: The fictional 'Genetic Character' memes promote the scientifically incorrect idea that specific racial groups have inherent personality traits encoded in their DNA, using manipulated charts as evidence. [Document ID: 4]
'Racial Harmony Quotient' memes use a fictional 0-100 scale to rank countries by racial integration, presenting entirely made-up statistics as factual international measurements. [Document ID: 9]

'Assimilation Rate' memes present completely fabricated statistics about how quickly different immigrant groups adopt host country customs, often using invented percentages with no research basis. [Document ID: 1]
The 'Racial Barometer' meme series falsely claims to measure 'racial authenticity' through arbitrary cultural preferences, gaining popularity despite having no sociological validity. [Document ID: 7]

The 'Triple Heritage Theory' popularized through Instagram memes incorrectly suggests that racial stereotypes always contain three distinct cultural elements combined from different ethnic groups. [Document ID: 2]
